transcript: How to fix sciatica in 14 days. A recent study conducted by the American College of Physicians found that in 93% of cases, sciatica is caused by a herniated or slipped disc. That's when a disc moves out of place, putting pressure on the sciatic nerve and the nerve root. This is what's causing that sharp, shooting pain that can travel down one or both of your legs. So, what's the reason behind a herniated or slipped disc? Well, you know how everyone always says you gotta sit up straight. We hear this every day, and we all know how important it is to maintain a correct posture while sitting. But for some reason, after 10 minutes of sitting, we end up looking like this. No harm done if you slouch for 20 minutes in your office chair, right? Well, that's true, but here's the catch. When you spend hours on end every day sitting in that position, that's when things start to go wrong. You see, when we sit all slouched in our chairs, we're not really using our core muscles like we should be if we were sitting up straight. Over time, those muscles weaken and become inactive. So instead of our core muscles doing their job, the pressure is now being taken on by our cervical discs, which is not what they were designed for. As if this wasn't enough, there's one more thing. As we get older, our spinal discs lose water content and become less flexible. This makes them more vulnerable to damage and injury. Now you know the real reason why sitting up straight is important, right? It can prevent the damage in your back. But here's the catch. If you're already dealing with sciatica, just sitting up straight won't magically fix the issue. So what can we do? There are chiropractors. They're great at realigning the spine and relieving the pain, but you're forced to go in two to three times a week, which can cost hundreds of dollars a week. And when you stop going, the pain comes back because you're not really addressing the root cause of the sciatica. And there are painkillers, which are great at providing short-term relief, but it's only a surface-level treatment. And once the effect wears off, the pain returns. Luckily, a top chiropractor developed a breakthrough solution that's guaranteed to fix your sciatica in 30 days, or your money back. As suppliers to over 49 chiropractic clinics worldwide who in unison have treated tens of thousands of patients with our product, we're able to analyze the backs of over 9,547 patients suffering from sciatica. We took that specific information to make adjustments with our in-house chiropractor. 13 months, 26 prototypes, and five clinical trials later, we finally invented a solution that targets the true root cause of sciatica by mimicking the core muscles while boosting the blood flow to the lower back area and decompressing the spine. It's called the Dainley Belt, and we just got it FDA-approved at the end of 2022. The secret is the patented double compression zone technology, which applies targeted medical compression on the hip area. So here's the thing. Those core muscles of yours, they're the real heroes. And when they're strained and overworked, they need a little help to get back to their best. That's where the Dainley Belt comes in. It promotes nutrient-rich blood flow to those hard-working muscles, which helps them reactivate and take some of the pressure off your spine. When that happens, your spinal discs decompress, and voila. Say goodbye to sciatica, and hello to pure.
label: High

transcript: Why are people with sciatica switching to the Dainley belt? I've been suffering from sciatica for about two years now. It came on suddenly one day and continued to come and go with my thigh muscle, also contracting by itself, but in the last few months it has got much, much worse, up until the point where it became constant. My doc sent me for two MRIs, and he said that my sciatic nerve had no room to move, as it got pinched because of a herniated disc between the L4 and L5 vertebrae. Since then I've been taking painkillers constantly. I've tried ibuprofen and naproxen, then naphepam, with little to no relief. And then my doc said that the next step would be something stronger, like gabapentin, or even a cortisone injection. I started taking gabapentin, and honestly, it didn't take the pain away completely, but at least it made it bearable. But then I had a four-hour car journey, and it was agony. I couldn't get comfortable in any position, couldn't lie down in the back seat, because my dog takes up a lot of space. I asked myself, is this the life I'm going to live from now on? Unable to walk for as long as I'd like, and now unable to even sit for a couple of hours when I'm traveling. I told myself that from now on, every single day, I'll be searching for a cure, and if I find one, I'll share it with everyone else. I started going to a chiropractor, and mine is actually very good. I'd probably say one of the best in the state. After his appointments, I started feeling better, but after a couple hours, the pain kept roaring back, laughing at my efforts, and it would fully return if I missed an appointment. One appointment would cost me $100, and I needed three per week to get pain relief. Unfortunately, that's too expensive, and my wallet hurts as much as my back does. I had to stop going, continue with those damn pills. Then I noticed that I'm getting addicted to gabapentin, and if I stopped taking it, I'd start having withdrawal symptoms. And that was a big red flag for me. I really needed to find a way to stop the pain and quit taking those pills. So about two months ago, I really took things seriously and started researching everything there is to know about sciatica. I read hundreds of posts on forums dedicated to sciatica and lower back pain. I watched YouTube videos. I joined Facebook groups where people were suffering from sciatica and sharing their experience. I subscribed to health magazines. I started reading articles and meeting with doctors, and even started reading books on this matter. That's how determined I was to find a solution. After weeks of research, I found a case study made by Dr. Steve Brown, a renowned neurologist from Chicago. He explained why sciatica gets so unbearable and how to deal with it, which helped me a lot. The bad news was that I found out that there's really no cure for a herniated disc, and anyone telling you the opposite simply wants to profit from your pain. Yes, you can have surgery, but that's invasive. It costs tens of thousands of dollars, and you get a 50% chance of success. However, there are ways to significantly reduce the pain and not let this condition get worse. Let me explain what I found out, because this is what made a world of difference for me. Working demanding jobs or sitting for prolonged periods of time puts a lot of pressure on your spine as you age. Because of this, your vertebrae compress and start squeezing like those gel-like discs located between them. Those discs are made from a soft gelatinous core on the inside and a thick outer ring on the outside. When a disc gets compressed excessively, the soft inner core breaks through the thick outer ring, and that's what we call a herniated disc. But it's not always painful. It's not the disc itself that's causing you the pain. The pain occurs when the herniated disc pinches your sciatic nerve, and that's what causes the burning pain down your back, buttocks, and legs. That's what happened to me. There is not a single pill, massager, or chiropractor that can repair a herniated disc once the thick outer ring is broken. That's how it remains. The pain coming from sciatica is absolutely debilitating, and if we leave it like that, it only gets worse and worse up to the point where you literally can't move anymore. And unfortunately, I had days exactly like that. Now that after weeks of research, I finally understood why I was hurting, I started looking for ways to reverse the damage and relieve the pain. I tried those inversion tables, but imagine trying to get down from one when your back is spasming and you feel like you're getting cut in half. All I got from it was an expensive headache. I also tried countless products from Amazon that promised the world, and failed to deliver. And to be honest, for a moment I got discouraged that after almost five weeks of research, I didn't find anything that really worked. Then, thank God, about three weeks ago, I found an online forum dedicated specifically to people suffering from lower back pain and sciatica, where literally thousands of people were telling their stories of how they are fighting this terrible pain. I stumbled on a post from four months ago where someone was saying that the only thing that helped him relieve his back pain and sciatica is this device. There were over 3,000 responses to that post, and most of them were from people who tried this weird-looking belt for themselves and said that it was working wonders. It's called the Danely Belt. It was developed by Adam Fischt, one of the best chiropractors in the US, and he said that all you need to do is wear this belt for two hours a day over a period of two to three weeks. It has this patented double compression zone technology, where you basically adjust the level of compression with those elastic white straps. A lot of people were saying that it works, so I decided, hey, what's a few more bucks to all the years I spent hurting? I went to the only place where this belt is available to order, at danelylab.com, and I noticed that they had 60-day results or full refund guarantee. So I basically, if I didn't feel any better after using it, I was going to get my money back anyway. No risk. I got it delivered to my door just about two weeks ago, and here it is. So on the first day, I put it on, not expecting much because I've been let down countless times before. But get this. After about 15 minutes of wearing this belt, my sciatica went from an eight to a two from the first day. Can you imagine? I don't know what magic potion they put in it, and I honestly don't care. What matters for me is that I was finally able to walk, sit, and rest normally for the first time in years. I kept using it every single day for two hours, as the instructions said, and gradually, my pain began to subside more and more each day. Two weeks in, and I'm able to stand for hours with no pain, even when I don't wear the belt. Finally, my legs don't feel like they've been pounded by hammers all day. My lower back feels so much better too. The thing actually did its job. This actually worked. I've read the information from their website, and apparently, this belt offers extra support at the base of my spine, while also boosting the blood flow in the underlying tissue to accelerate the healing process. This helped my back muscle strengthen to decompress my spine and relieve the pressure from my sciatic nerve. I can't tell you how happy I am right now. I probably sound like a broken record to my family, but believe me, once you go through two years of not being able to bend forward to tie your shoelaces, or walk more than ten minutes without feeling like your back is getting drilled into, being pain-free is like you're a whole new person. So please, don't make the same mistake as I did. Don't get stuck on pills for so many years, and don't allow yourself to suffer so horribly from sciatica, lower back pain, and those damned hernias.
label: High

You see, lower back pain and sciatica are most often caused because of a herniated or a slipped disc that's touching the sciatic nerve. Now you're asking, wait, what's a herniated or slipped disc? And then between them there are these gel-like discs which act like cushions to prevent excessive strain or movement. But what if you didn't feel the pain from touching the hot stove? Doesn't that mean your hand is going to get injured? Well, yeah, you'd probably get a really bad injury because you hold your hand on the stove for longer than you should if you just pulled it away with the pain. That's what painkillers do. Now, he was one of the first doctors who investigated the link between deep, stabilizing muscles that are in our lower back and then the compressed spine. See, there's something deep in the lower back called the ialisis muscle, and this tiny muscle is the number one cause of sciatica and lower back pain. For such a small muscle, it sure causes a huge number of problems. So you probably didn't know this, but sitting puts more pressure on your spine than standing, and that is where the ialisis muscle gets very tight. The odds are you're actually sitting and destroying your back right now. And the longer you stay seated, the tighter the ialisis muscle gets. When a disc gets compressed excessively, the soft inner core breaks through the thick outer ring, and that's what we call a herniated disc. But it's not always painful. It's not the disc itself that's causing you the pain. The pain occurs when the herniated disc pinches your sciatic nerve, and that's what causes the burning pain down your back, buttocks, and legs. A lot of people were saying that it works, so I decided, hey, what's a few more bucks to all the years I spent hurting?
